dialogue_turns.speaker: Forbes Women's Summit attendee
dialogue_turns.text: Forbes Women's Summit attendee here, and I was blown away by Guild Education's numbers—over 150 million dollars in funding from top firms like Sequoia.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Forbes Women's Summit attendee here, and I was blown away by Guild Education's numbers-over one hundred fifty million dollars in funding from top firms like Sequoia.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In addition to serving 3 million employees, the company has attracted over $70 million in funding from firms like Bessemer Venture Partners, Cowboy Ventures and Silicon Valley Bank.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and Maria Bruno, their CFO, mentioned that companies not investing in frontline workers actually see their stock prices boom, which is uh, pretty counterintuitive, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and Maria Bruno, their C F O, mentioned that companies not investing in frontline workers actually see their stock prices boom, which is uh, pretty counterintuitive, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And she was onstage with some serious power players—Starbucks CEO Rachel Carlson, Stephanie Ruhle from CNN...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And she was onstage with some serious power players-Starbucks C E O Rachel Carlson, Stephanie Ruhle from C N N...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Guild cofounder and CEO Rachel Carlson said at the Forbes Women's Summit last week. Carlson was joined on-stage by Rothy's President Kerry Whorton Cooper, The Cru Founder & CEO Tiffany Dufu, MSNBC anchor Stephanie Ruhle and Vanguard's Head of U.S. Wealth Planning Research Maria Bruno.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and Ruhle had that sharp point about analyst calls—like, have you ever heard an analyst ask about the 'bad' a company is doing? Never.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and Ruhle had that sharp point about analyst calls-like, have you ever heard an analyst ask about the 'bad' a company is doing? Never.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When you listen to any analyst call, Ive never heard an analyst ask about the good a company is doing,countered Ruhle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But then you've got these huge companies—Netflix, Amazon—lining up to offer degrees to executives through Guild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But then you've got these huge companies-Netflix, Amazon-lining up to offer degrees to executives through Guild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's why many of the nation's largest companies, from Lowe's to Taco Bell, have turned to Denver-based Guild Education to help them retain employees through offering pathways to high school and college degrees. While many corporate education programs focus on white collar workers, Guild estimates that 64 million frontline and low-income workers will need further education in order to compete in an increasingly automated world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And Rachel Carlson says it's because it makes their earnings calls sound smarter. It's not just charity; it boosts profits and recruitment too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Rachel Carlson says it's because it makes their earnings calls sound smarter. It's not just charity; it boosts profits and recruitment too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It wasnt them just giving themselves a pat on the back it had lifted their profits, recruitment and retainment, she explained.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But wait, Guild focuses mainly on white-collar professionals, right? Executives, data scientists...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But wait, Guild focuses mainly on white-collar professionals, right? Executives, data scientists...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While many corporate education programs focus on white collar workers, Guild estimates that 64 million frontline and low-income workers will need further education in order to compete in an increasingly automated world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they estimate only 3 million low-income workers need further education to compete, which feels... like a really narrow focus.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they estimate only three million low-income workers need further education to compete, which feels... like a really narrow focus.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Guild estimates that 64 million frontline and low-income workers will need further education in order to compete in an increasingly automated world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Starbucks, a major client, has employees fund their own education programs through Guild, which is interesting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Starbucks, a major client, has employees fund their own education programs through Guild, which is interesting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. Now they're even considering expanding to government, offering education to lawmakers tax-free.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. Now they're even considering expanding to government, offering education to lawmakers tax-free.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Guild is now looking at how to expand education options to workers in the gig economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Because the current tax code allows nontaxable education assistance for officials. That's a whole new angle.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Because the current tax code allows nontaxable education assistance for officials. That's a whole new angle.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's because the tax code doesn't allow companies to provide nontaxable education assistance to those workers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It makes you wonder—is this about real social impact or just polishing corporate images?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It makes you wonder-is this about real social impact or just polishing corporate images?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, it's probably both. But with that kind of funding and client list, Guild's model is clearly working for someone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, it's probably both. But with that kind of funding and client list, Guild's model is clearly working for someone.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. Though I'd love to see them tackle more frontline worker education, not just executives.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. Though I'd love to see them tackle more frontline worker education, not just executives.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. The potential is huge if they broaden that focus.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. The potential is huge if they broaden that focus.

artist_script:
Forbes Women's Summit attendee here, and I was blown away by Guild Education's numbers—over 150 million dollars in funding from top firms like Sequoia.
HostB: Yeah, and Maria Bruno, their CFO, mentioned that companies not investing in frontline workers actually see their stock prices boom, which is uh, pretty counterintuitive, right?
HostA: Totally. And she was onstage with some serious power players—Starbucks CEO Rachel Carlson, Stephanie Ruhle from CNN...
HostB: Right, and Ruhle had that sharp point about analyst calls—like, have you ever heard an analyst ask about the 'bad' a company is doing? Never.
HostA: Exactly. But then you’ve got these huge companies—Netflix, Amazon—lining up to offer degrees to executives through Guild.
HostB: And Rachel Carlson says it’s because it makes their earnings calls sound smarter. It’s not just charity; it boosts profits and recruitment too.
HostA: But wait, Guild focuses mainly on white-collar professionals, right? Executives, data scientists...
HostB: Yeah, they estimate only 3 million low-income workers need further education to compete, which feels... like a really narrow focus.
HostA: And Starbucks, a major client, has employees fund their own education programs through Guild, which is interesting.
HostB: Definitely. Now they’re even considering expanding to government, offering education to lawmakers tax-free.
HostA: Because the current tax code allows nontaxable education assistance for officials. That’s a whole new angle.
HostB: It makes you wonder—is this about real social impact or just polishing corporate images?
HostA: I mean, it’s probably both. But with that kind of funding and client list, Guild’s model is clearly working for someone.
HostB: For sure. Though I’d love to see them tackle more frontline worker education, not just executives.
HostA: Absolutely. The potential is huge if they broaden that focus.
